awd_titl_txt: US-Cameroon Workshop on Sociolinguistic Language Documentation in Sub-Saharan Africa in Conjunction with the Seventh World Congress of African Linguistics, August 2012
awd_abstract_narration:
CNIC: U.S.-Cameroon Workshop on Sociolinguistic Language Documentation in Sub-Saharan Africa in Conjunction with the Seventh World Congress of African Linguistics (WOCAL), August 2012  

This award supports a catalytic activity initiated by Dr. Jeffrey Good, State University of New York at Buffalo with Dr. Pius Tamanji, Department of African Languages and Linguistics, University of Yaoundé, Cameroon to promote new international collaborations with African scholars.  To that end, the US-Cameroon workshop on sociolinguistic language documentation in Sub-Saharan Africa will be held in conjunction with the Seventh World Congress of African Linguistics in August 2012.  

Coordination of the workshop with a major international conference where leading scholars present their research and plan future projects is the ideal intellectual setting to maximize the impact of the three-day workshop and draw attention to sociolinguistic language documentation as an important area for research.  The focus on Sub-Saharan Africa where there are complex dynamics between societies and languages provides unique opportunities as well as an ideal testing ground for developing theories and models for sociolinguistic language documentation.  Selected working group reports will be prepared for publication and made available online.  Most importantly, the development of specific research projects and partnerships is an expected outcome of this workshop.     

More broadly, the workshop will include U.S. graduate students, a significant number of African scholars, and participants from under-represented groups in research.  Tutorials will be held on relevant sociolinguistic topics during the WOCAL to provide attendees training opportunities.   The focus on a largely unexplored research topic with applications to work on language planning and maintenance make it of potential benefit to under-resourced language groups within Sub-Saharan Africa and beyond.  Especially significant is that the results of this workshop are likely to be of interest to Africans concerned with issues of language policy and education, where a better understanding of the social context of multilingualism would be of high value. This award is jointly funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering and the SBE/BCS Documenting Endangered Languages Program.

por.por_cntn:
Recent decades have seen increasing interest in the documentation of minority languages, in particular endangered languages. One of the goals of this work is to ensure that we have a record of contemporary linguistic diversity on the planet given current trends of linguistic and cultural homogenization triggered by processes of globalization. While significant strides have been made to document endangered languages, most work along these lines has focused on documenting the properties of individual languages rather than considering how these languages reflect, and play a role in constructing, the social lives of their speakers. The primarily goal of this project was to rigorously explore how to develop a research agenda that would expand language documentation activities into sociolinguistic domains.

The project's focus was on Sub-Saharan Africa due to the fact that the sociolinguistic patterns found in much of Sub-Saharan Africa have long been known to be quite distinct from those found in the Western environments that have informed much of sociolinguistic research. In particular, many parts of Sub-Saharan African are characterized by pervasive multilingualism and comparatively weak language-nation links, which is in contrast to what is seen, for instance, in the United States, where there are strong social pressures towards being monolingual in English throughout the country.

The major project activity consisted of organizing and running a workshop on the topic of sociolinguistic language documentation in Sub-Saharan Africa in conjunction with the sixth World Congress of African Linguistics (WOCAL), which took place at the University of Buea, Cameroon. Co-locating the workshop with this conference allowed for a larger and more diverse range of participants than would otherwise have been possible. The workshop was successfully held from 17-19 August 2012. More than sixty participants from the U.S., Europe, and throughout Sub-Saharan Africa attended (many on their own funds). A large number of participants were students and scholars from African countries with limited academic resources, and this workshop provided a valuable training and networking opportunity for them.

A paper detailing the results of the workshop, entitled, "Beyond the ancestral code: Towards a model for sociolinguistic language documentation", will be published in the open-access journal Language Documentation & Conservation. This will ensure the results are widely disseminated and accessible to scholars all over the world as well as to the general public. In the long run, increased work on the sociolinguistics of African languages, which this project is intended to encourage, will allow for more informed language policies to be developed for Sub-Saharan African countries characterized by significant linguistic diversity, in particular in the domain of education.
